adventures that attend these amphiblous oe-
incs who traverse the onfstrctched ~orla
of waters in quest Oceans unctuous mon
arch. But the most Peclous incidents are
encountered BY those daring mariners, VINO

In the month Of December, the summer
of the southern hemisphere, -Nantucket
shin was cruising ON the coast OF Chilli
Nothing could exceed the placid smoothness
of the seas, or the pelucid azure of the O.
ycrbaneing frmament. There was just e.
noueh motion i'll the atmosphere to propel
the vessel in her course, and to invigorate
her crew with the spirit of enterprise. tlv-
ery sail was set, and every bosom swelsed
with the hope Of speedy accomplishment
Of the object of their expedition. he con
tinent. and all the usual abodes OF mortals,
were tar, far away. Home, and its sweet
entiearments, were remembered as q Dy-
gone vision; and considered in the future.
as saints think of heaven. The occasional
scream of an albatross, circling III the blue
expanse-the monotonous dash OF the shlp's
stem through the scarcely resisting waters
-intermingled with the varied tones OF
few human voices conversing familarly on
the deck, were the only sounds which dis
tinguished that region from the pvlmeval
| reign of


"Silence, coeyal with Eternity


Suddenly, hollow, kissing, eructaton,
like the blast OF brazier's furnace, or the
sigh of a DIVING volcano, broke upon the
ready ears of the seamen. A cry from the
masthead announced the appearance of
their prey; and at the same instant the crew
found themselves surrounded on all sides oy
an extensive shoal of whales, floundering,
and spouting, and blowing, like 50 many
English trumpeters at the battle OF Water
loo. Forthwith three boats were lowered,
manned, and Supplied with all the usual
paraphanalia, harpoons, lances, towllnes,
waits, oars and paddles; with q sail, bag
of bread, and key of water to each. They
had but a short distance to row. ere they
came in contact with their mighty enemy.
The boats were severaly commanded by
the shipmastcr and two of his mates, assist
ed by their respective boatsteerers, to whom
the duty of striking the whale is ordinarily
assigned. The larboard waist boat. under
the second mates direction contained in its
bow an active young man; who had obtain
ed the esteem Of all his shipmasess and

A little money is good thing in the out
set of life, if a person has wisdom to make
right and iudicious use of it. But the head
and the pocket must balance well-the scale
must be equipoised-for if one or the other
kicks the beam, a loss will in most cases en-
sue. If you have too little wit, the world
will over-reach you; it too much, you Will
out wit Yourself. In either case, ten chan
ces to one, your purse or rather the con-
tents Of it, will slip through your fingers
Among the dangers to which hereditary
wealth subiectsus, are pride, incidence, ex-
travagance, and the smaller the portion of
our inheritance, the more danger is there
But what is most extraordinary is, that these
very evils, are often nursed up in the era
die with the child, cherished with growth,
and instiled into all his habits as he passes
through the routine of his education, by pa
rental care and misjudging affection.


Cornela was an heiress. That is, she was
worth some thousands OF dollars-l never
knew exactly the sum; common report
speaks the whole truth in these matters, and


it is rather unmannerly to inquire very par
ticularly into lady's fortune.


She was ndulged by her kind friends a
broad-sent to the most fashionable school.
The mistress duly advised that she was a
peculiarly delicate girl, with most exquisite
sensibiities, and rare genius; and was to be
treated with all becoming tenderness and
consideration. There she learned few OF
the useful and greatmany ofthe ornament
al branches taught in such seminaries; and
was finally despatched to "a boarding school
to finish her education; with which the ad-
jective "usetul," had very little, if any thing
to do.


She was now an accomplished lady-she
understood French and painting-was vers-
ed in Bellies Lettres-knew something OF
philosophy, natural and mora-had gone
| the round of the sciences; wrote poetry;
kept an album; understood music; and was
| finally fitted out at home with fine parlor
and a piano. "What fine lady"-said the
wondering viilagers-"what fine lady
how fashionable-how perfectly genteel."
1t is even so; and the first difficulty which
arose, was about the choice of that vexatious
but necessary eyil--a husband. The pret-
| ty girl who has the whole wcrld of beauty
to choose from, sometimes finds it difficult
to make perfect unoblectionable choice. 1t
was not to be wondered at that Cornelia
should be embarrassed in making selection
- for she was circumscribed in her sphere

lcft home with his family 70 pick hops. Be-

by the very small compass Of perfectly gen
teel people like herself. Such an one with
a good subtantial fortune too, was to be
sourht.-Her stars favored her at last, how
ever. and she was married--marricd to a
Young gentlemen as accomplished as her.
self; one who had as many eulogies at his
finger ends, as buttons on his coat-an a.
b. and a profession; who drove tandem with
one hand; winged pigeon at every shot,
and drank nothing but Madeira.


1t was said the young gentleman and la
DIV were each little disappointed in the
matter of the others fortune, and that in
the outset there was tritlng jar onthe sub
ect Of finances, but Cornelia adhered to
her piano, and Bob to his rifle and Made
ria, and all went on quite musically again.
Neither OF them had ever suffered SO un-
manncrly thought, as that how to gct a
living when their cash was gone, enter their
head--but fortune in all these cases, has
plain matter of TACT way of dealing, with G.
ven the most gentccl people, and when they
spent their last dollar, just turns them out OF
house, as unceremoniously as it they were
no better than common folks.-She never
works n miracle to sustain those VINO new
er learned or had the disposition to work
anv thing themselves. And so it turned out
i'll this case.


While the piatlu IL tune in the par

en-; while the master drank MADEIRA above

about a toilet, and therefore as might al

! Still SO far as physical ability was concern
cd it was not too late perhaps TO turn the
current Of affairs. There was a plain and
ready remedy for the disease, even in its
present state; an entire change OF living
and of habits; economy for Extravaganza
and industry for incidence. But hard it is
for these who have been thus educated to
/ change how often is the moral ability, the
! will wanting And here it proved to be the
case.


They struggled awhile to keep up appear
ance, and only sunk deeper in the end. len
wears after, thcy were almost forgotten. |
4 made many enquiries after them among the
villagers, and finally discovered that Robert
and his wife had separated; that he had eX-
changed his dog and gun for tar hat and
j blue Jacket, was wanderer on the sea; and
the elegant and accomplished Corntla, IN
stead of drumming piano, was gaming .
scanty subsistence At the spinning wheel
j So much for the story. Industry and vir'
tue are the best legacies parents can be-
queath to their offspring; the only sure de-
FENCES against misfortune. Let those who
are charged with the education Of children
beware. lest through an over anxiety tc


make them resncctable; to make them


proud, instead of cultivatng their genius,
! lead them to indoence. ! say beware

Every one must recollect the traglcal sto-
ry of Young Elnmet tue Irish Patriot, It was
too touching to be soon forgotten During
the troubles in Ireland he was tried, con-
demncd, and executed on charge Of trea-
son. His fate made 4 deep impression on
public sympathy. He was 50 young; 50 N
selligent; 50 generous; SO bravc; so every
thing that we are apt to like in young man


His conduct under trial, too, was Lofty
and intrepid. The noiie indignation with
which he repealed the charge q treason a

The love of life is one of the most useful


and important priucinlcs of human nature;
and death, the necessary end OF all men, is
an event, mercifu!ly and in wisdom hid from
our eyes. Hoping that we may live till to-
morrow, we feel ourselves to day, to make
some provisions for it. Not knowing the
time of their death, men are engaged to.acts
as if they were immortal. And though no
wise man would "wish to live always" or
can deem it possible. yet the precise period
never comes, when we find ourselves SO en-
tirely unoccupied with temporal prospects
or pursuits, 30 totally mortified with the
world as to be disposed with cheerfulness to
leave it.-Hence the business OF the world
goes on, which would otherwise stand still;
and that God of whose years there can be
no end, is carving on designs of everlasting
moment. by frail and short lived instruments.
This man makes few feeble dying efforts,
and expires. Another comes after him,
takes UP the instrument which his fellow
had laid down, makes his stroke or TWO,
and exprca likewise; and yet by means OF
efforts so weak, so interrupted, and sell de-
stroyng, the purposes OF Heaven proceed,
the building Of God rises, every loss is IN
stantly repaired, every defect supplied, nc
chasn, in the chain of Providence is permit
ted to take place. Hence men are disnihed
with the title of fellow workers OF God, and
the perishing attempts OF Pcri'hng crea-
lures, are employed i'll maturing the plans ol
infinite wisdom, and arc honored by the &C
ceptance and appropriation OF linn whe
"worketh all things after the counsel OF his
own wilt" What a motive to diligence,
cxertion and perseverance


1t is said that we may safely leave rcli-
eion to itself; and that the work OF God, II
really his work, will be able to stand OF itself
and can require no human aid 1t would be
sufficient answer to this sophism, that II
would be conclusive against all efforts OF all
sects for the religious instruction and I'M
provcment of the human race, and would
reduce us all, as respects religion to crea-
lures of necessity, for why should there DC
any preacher to teach, if it is to be commu-
| nicated without teaching? But this is not


the principal either of reason or religion
| The manifest reason is, that God always


works by secondary causes, and requires the
best exercise of our rational powers; and oul
means of all kinds, both to receive religious
| instruction for ourselves, and 10 convey 1t &c


others; and that in proportion as NATIONS Of
| individuals possess these means, they are
answerablc to him for the due and right use
of them. There are therefore two main
reasons for religious instruction, the first oul
duty to ourselves, inasmuch as God requires
this duty of us an act of service and homage


to Him, and without any reference 70 tle


certainty of success, and secondly as duty


to our neighhors. We are bound to maks


the attempt however unpromisng as an ac
| of service, and of obedience to God, and we
are bound TO persevere in it, because the


slightest success is a good communicated tt


our neighbor, and reward insured to our


selves infinitely above all the possible cos'


of mere money and personal pains.

we extract the following pathetic balla
rom the last number of the London Literar
Gazette received at this Office. 1t is take
rom an amusing work lately published
fordon. under the title of Ithims and odd
.es in prose and verse, by Thomas Hood.


" Y. Statesman.
Ben Battle was soldier bold,
And used to wars alarms,
But cannon ball took off his legs,
So lie laid down his arms!
Now as thev bore him off the field,
Said he, s'let others shoot,
For here leave my second leg,
And the sForty.second Foot
The army.snrgeons made him limbsi
Said he, they're only pegs;
But there's as wooden members quite
As represent my lcgs!'
Now Ben he loved pretty maid,
Her name was Nelly Gray;
So he went to pay her his dcvours,
Wien he dcvour'd his pay!
But when he calld on Nelly Gray,
She made him quite a scott;
And when she saw his wooden legs,
Began to take them off!
% Nelly Gray! o Nelly Gray!
Is this your love SO warm
The love that loves scarlet coat,
Should be more uniform!
Said she, q loy'l soldier once,
For he was blthe and brayei
But will never have a man


With both legs in the grave!
Before you had those timber toes,
Your love did allow;
But then, you know, you stand upon
Another footing now!'
20 Nelly Gray! Nelly Gray!
For all your jeering speeches,
At duty's call left my lcgs


In Badajos' breachesh
why them said she, you've lost the feet
Oflegs in wars alarms;
And now you cannot wearyour shoes
Upon your feats of alins!'
false and tickle Nelly Gray


know why you refuse;
Tho I've no feet, some other man
lsstandng in my shoes!
wish ne.er had seen your facei
But now long farewell!
For ysu will be my death-alas


You will not be my NeH"
Now when he went from Nelly Gray.


His heart so heavy got,
And life was such burden grown


1t made him take knot!
So round his melancholy neck


rope he did entwine,
And, for the second time in life,


Enlisted in the Line!
One end he tied around beam,


And then remov'd his pegs
And, as his legs We're Off, Of course,


lie soon was off his legs!
And ,tere he hung till he was dead
As any nail in town;
For no distress had cut him up,


II could not cut him down.
dozen men sat on his corpse,


10 lind out why he died;
And they buried Ben in four crossroads,


With stake in his inside!

gainst his country; the eloquent yindication
of his name; and his pathetic appeal to pos
terity in the hopeless hour Of contemplation;
all these entered deeply into every generous
bosom, and even his opponents lamented the
stern policy that dictated his execution.


But there was one heart whose anguish it
would be impossible to describe. In haPpi-
er days and fairer fortunes he had won the
affections OF beautiful and interesting girl,
the daughter of the late celebrated Irish
barrister. She loved him with the disiuter-
ested fervor of a woman's first and early
love. When every worldly maxim arrayed
itself against him, when blasted in fortune.
and disgrace and danger darkened around
his name, she loved him the more ardently
for his sufferings. Since his fate could a.
waken sympathy even of his foes, what must
have been the agony of her, whose soul was
occupied by his image? Let those tell who
have had the portals of the tomb suddenly
closed between them and the being they
most loved ON earth; who have sat at its
threshold, as one shut out in cold and lcne-
ly world, whence all that was lovely and low
ing had departed.


To render her widowed situation more
desolate, she had incurred her fathers dis
pleasure by her unfortunate attachment,
and was an exile from the paternal roof
But could the sympathy and kind offices OF
friends have reached spirit so shocked and
driven in by horror, she would have expert
enced no want of consolation, for the Irish
are people of quick and generous sensibili-
ties. The most delicate and cherishing at
tentions were paid her by families of wealth
| and distinction.--She was led into society,
and they tried all kinds of occupation and
amusement, to dissipate her grief, wean her
from the tragical story of her love, but all
was in vain! There are some strokes of ca
lamity that scathe and scorch the soul--that
penetrate to the vital seat of happiness, and
blast it, never again to put forth bud or blos-
som. She never objected to frequent the
haunts OF otpleasure; but she was as much a.
lone there as in the depths Of Solitude. She
| carried with her an inward woe, that mock
ed all the Establishments of friendship, and
"heeded not the song of the charmer; charm
lie ever so wisely"


The person, says the eloquent author Of
the Sketch Book, who told me her storys
had seen her at masquerade. After STROLL
ing through the splendid rooms and giddy
crowd, with an air of utter abstraction, she
sat herself down on the steps of an orchestra,
and looking about for some time with va
cant air, that showed her insensbility tsthe
garlsh scene, she began with the capricious-
ness of heart, to warble a little plaintive air.
She had an exquisite voice; but on this occa-
sion was so simple, so touching, it breathed
forth such soul of wretchedness that sh~
drew crowd, mute and silent are..iio her.
and melted every one into tears.
The story of one SO true and tender, could
not but excite great interest in a country re-
markable for enthusiasm. 1t completely
won the heart OF a brave officer, who paid
his addresses to her, and thought that one SO
! t,u,a to tbaf RI ..J J,,.
tomato to the living. She declined his atten-
tions, tor her thoughts were rrevocably en-
crossed by the memory of her former lover.
He solicited not her tenderness, but her es-
TEEN. lie was assisted by her conviction Of
his worth, and her sense OF her own destitute
and dependant situation, for she was exist
ing on the kindness of friends In word
he at length succeeded in gaining her hand,
/ though with a solemn assurance that her
heart was unalterably anothcr's.


| He took her with him to Sicily, heping
that change of scene might wear out the
remembrance of early woes. She was an
amiable and exemplary wife, and made an
effort to be happy one; but nothing could
cure the silent melancholy that had entered
into her very soul. She wasted away in q
slow but hopeless decline, and at last sunk
into the grave, the victim of a broken heart.
~ "Ho va t'io tooJ, tuae AFAOOiC SoNlPOaS
ed the following lines:


She is fur from the land where her young hero


sleeps,


| And lovers around her are signing;


But codly she turns from their gaze and weeps.


For her heart in his grave is lying


She sings the wild song of her dear native plains,
! Every note which he lov'd awaking;


All! little they think, who delight in her strains,
I How the heart Of the minstrel is breaking!


lie had lived for his love-for his country he


died,


They were all that to life had entwn'd him,


Nor soon shall the tears Of his country DC dried.


Nor long will his love stay behind ln''


OH make her grave whore the s,nbeams rest,


When they promise glorious mor"ow;
They'll slime Ger her sleep, like smile from the
1 west,


From her own loy'd Island of sorrow!
A PROFLIGATE PIG.


~. ,rnaeI.v a Dersou living in Maidstone

who we shall introdue to our readers under
the name of Jonah Coffin. Poising his har-
poon, he firmly awaited the orders of his su-
perior, then seated on the boats stern. Be-
fore him, forcing itself furiously onward,
was huge andupcouth mass, alternately e.
mittng from its glossy protuberances, the
sparkling effulgcnce of a meridian sun, or
partially descending below the temporary
surge, forming little vortices to its wake,
and putting from its nostris the encroaching
brine. Long and patiently did the oarsmen
tug at their stations-"pull away" said the
officer encouragingly, while he drew towards
him the handle ef his steering oar. The We
nv eye of the monster was now in sight
'snow dart" exclaimed the mate; and Jo-
nah, with the effort OF Polyphemus, drove
the weapon. fast into the body of his gigantic
antagonist


It. was an awful moment; and the adven-
turous fishers had made every customary
preparation for its reception. But the OBJ


cct Of their toll. instead of dropping instan-
taneously into the depths beneath, thence a.
gain to emerge, after some moments, tor the
sake ofbrcath--or instead of starting Oft hor-
izontally, as is frequently the case, with the
velocity of lightning, dragging his presump-
tuous pursuers through the disparting wave,
which throws swiftly upon either side OF
their frail pinnance a transparent sheet of
spray, surmounted by gorgeous ranbows-
rolled backward, and with preternatural
frenzy made for the boat-his enormous
laws distcndcd to their utmost limits; and
lis tremendous tail now curvingi upwards,
and vibrating like a light house in an earth
quake, and anon falling with horrid flap up
on the level bosom of the sounding deep
The astonshca sailors we're about to rush
overheard, when, with convulsive sound,
1t was the leap of a mountan--the lace
rated monster sprang entirely over the boat,
his unearthly dimensions striking principal
ly upon the opposite side, and partly upon
the fragile bark itself, spiling its contents
and grinding its frame to splinters.


The men were all good swimmers, and,
save one, betook themselves, without farther
calculation, and with exemplary preciptan-
cy, to the profitable exercise Of their arms
and legs-whereby they soon reached the
boats Of their comrades, and were out of
danger. Not SO with poor Ionah.--In the
tumult of the moment, he had become en-
tangled in the tortuous coil attached to the
harpoon. Not AN instant had been allowed
lin, wherein he might haye seized the
Ratchet, or unsheathed his jacknife, and
freed himself from SO ungracous predica-
meut. He felt himself drawn, by an ire
sstible power, down, down, amidst intermi-
nable cavcrns, and bottomless profundties.
| What greatly surprised him, was his ability
still to breathe and to see. Passing, with
the rapitlity Of thought, along immeasurable
distances, he had opportunities to scan but
few Of the wonders of those vast quits,
| Here lay an extensive forest Of coral, inhab-
! tied BY shapes abe--there moved
an immense mass of gelatnous matter, en-
compasscd by myriads of submarine prodi-
| gies, to piscivorous man hitherto unknown.
| The a-devil, with his emerald horns; the
tartarean crab, with a million claws, each a
furlong in length; the ponderous symmesian
oyster, whose shells open wide enough to
admit a seventy-fOur; the thousand eyed
dragon, whose head, studded with a thou
sand gems, and whose eyes, set in countless
diamonds, may be seen at the depth of five
hundred fathoms; sta-gorgons, hydras, grif-


fins, phnnixes, and all manner Of beau
tiful reptiles, were quietly feeding, or frolc-
ing without any noise, in those unsearchable
regions.


| And here, some philosophers may be dis
posed to obtrude doubt, touching honest
I Jonah's capacity of vision and of respiration
the whilc.-Rut let it be inquired, whether
/ Il


with such outrageous celebrity, may not have
left behind sort of vacuity, aflording me-


dunn wherein the little animal in his rear
might exercise those faculties? And, re-


garding the accelerated progress of this


monster it may be aptly accounted for on
purely philosophical principles: every body


knows how fast dog will run with kettle
|
I But to our tale--iet us hasten to the ca


tastrophe. After being carried to such


lengths, and in such manner, our almost


exhausted hero, found himself on the ascent.


His wild and turbulent conductor was again


mounting to the upper world. Embracing a


moment of respite, while the whale was 10


the act of turning upon his side, he sought


his knife--but III yain--2 new motion dis


turbed him---he was waved to and fro with


an impetuous gularity--his lungs labour-


ed, and his sight grew indistinct--his breatl,


went, and came, and went, to return not


without inhaling also draught Of the saline


fluid. Alas thought he, am drowned =


Foggy images fioated on his brain, and grad


ually faded into otluscatioa. He awoke up


on the quarter deck of his own snip, under


the oepration OF stimula,i,e cordials and


warm towels; having been cast upon the


surface during the whales DIVING struggle


and picked up near the place Of his descent

MANY and strange are the accidents and
adventures that attend these amphiblous oe-
incs who traverse the onfstrctched ~orla
of waters in quest Oceans unctuous mon
arch. But the most Peclous incidents are
encountered BY those daring mariners, VINO
are engaged in the capture OF that spec,eS
of whale yclepcd herMacett-purSulhs tie
greasy monster throughout all his favoE!te
haunts and distant retreats i'll the broad ana
fathemless Pacific.


In the month Of December, the summer
of the southern hemisphere, -Nantucket
shin was cruising ON the coast OF Chilli
Nothing could exceed the placid smoothness
of the seas, or the pelucid azure of the O.
ycrbaneing frmament. There was just e.
noueh motion i'll the atmosphere to propel
the vessel in her course, and to invigorate
her crew with the spirit of enterprise. tlv-
ery sail was set, and every bosom swelsed
with the hope Of speedy accomplishment
Of the object of their expedition. he con
tinent. and all the usual abodes OF mortals,
were tar, far away. Home, and its sweet
entiearments, were remembered as q Dy-
gone vision; and considered in the future.
as saints think of heaven. The occasional
scream of an albatross, circling III the blue
expanse-the monotonous dash OF the shlp's
stem through the scarcely resisting waters
-intermingled with the varied tones OF
few human voices conversing familarly on
the deck, were the only sounds which dis
tinguished that region from the pvlmeval
| reign of


"Silence, coeyal with Eternity


Suddenly, hollow, kissing, eructaton,
like the blast OF brazier's furnace, or the
sigh of a DIVING volcano, broke upon the
ready ears of the seamen. A cry from the
masthead announced the appearance of
their prey; and at the same instant the crew
found themselves surrounded on all sides oy
an extensive shoal of whales, floundering,
and spouting, and blowing, like 50 many
English trumpeters at the battle OF Water
loo. Forthwith three boats were lowered,
manned, and Supplied with all the usual
paraphanalia, harpoons, lances, towllnes,
waits, oars and paddles; with q sail, bag
of bread, and key of water to each. They
had but a short distance to row. ere they
came in contact with their mighty enemy.
The boats were severaly commanded by
the shipmastcr and two of his mates, assist
ed by their respective boatsteerers, to whom
the duty of striking the whale is ordinarily
assigned. The larboard waist boat. under
the second mates direction contained in its
bow an active young man; who had obtain
ed the esteem Of all his shipmasess and

full articles.headline: From the Trenton Emporium.
full articles.article:
A little money is good thing in the out
set of life, if a person has wisdom to make
right and iudicious use of it. But the head
and the pocket must balance well-the scale
must be equipoised-for if one or the other
kicks the beam, a loss will in most cases en-
sue. If you have too little wit, the world
will over-reach you; it too much, you Will
out wit Yourself. In either case, ten chan
ces to one, your purse or rather the con-
tents Of it, will slip through your fingers
Among the dangers to which hereditary
wealth subiectsus, are pride, incidence, ex-
travagance, and the smaller the portion of
our inheritance, the more danger is there
But what is most extraordinary is, that these
very evils, are often nursed up in the era
die with the child, cherished with growth,
and instiled into all his habits as he passes
through the routine of his education, by pa
rental care and misjudging affection.


Cornela was an heiress. That is, she was
worth some thousands OF dollars-l never
knew exactly the sum; common report
speaks the whole truth in these matters, and


it is rather unmannerly to inquire very par
ticularly into lady's fortune.


She was ndulged by her kind friends a
broad-sent to the most fashionable school.
The mistress duly advised that she was a
peculiarly delicate girl, with most exquisite
sensibiities, and rare genius; and was to be
treated with all becoming tenderness and
consideration. There she learned few OF
the useful and greatmany ofthe ornament
al branches taught in such seminaries; and
was finally despatched to "a boarding school
to finish her education; with which the ad-
jective "usetul," had very little, if any thing
to do.


She was now an accomplished lady-she
understood French and painting-was vers-
ed in Bellies Lettres-knew something OF
philosophy, natural and mora-had gone
| the round of the sciences; wrote poetry;
kept an album; understood music; and was
| finally fitted out at home with fine parlor
and a piano. "What fine lady"-said the
wondering viilagers-"what fine lady
how fashionable-how perfectly genteel."
1t is even so; and the first difficulty which
arose, was about the choice of that vexatious
but necessary eyil--a husband. The pret-
| ty girl who has the whole wcrld of beauty
to choose from, sometimes finds it difficult
to make perfect unoblectionable choice. 1t
was not to be wondered at that Cornelia
should be embarrassed in making selection
- for she was circumscribed in her sphere

full articles.headline: a PROFLIGATE PIG.
full articles.article:
On Tuesday. aperson living in Maidstone,
lcft home with his family 70 pick hops. Be-


ing AFRAID that the pig in the stye might be
stolen, thcy transferred him to the cellar
After some time hjggy contrive9 to ascend
into the kitchen, and inspected the cupboard;
in that he found two pounds Of bacon, which


in most canniba like manner, he devour~
"a. His rcpast soon making him thirsty.
our hero, it is supposed, sought ABOUT 10,
something to ailay his thirst, and in tile
course .! his researches, he smelt some
thing savory in the upper regions. Accord
ingly he scrambled up stairs into bed room.
There he found wherewith to wash dowr.
the bacon, for on the floor s,ood several bot
ties Of elder berry wine. drawing ofcorks


he did not understand, but in cracking
bottle he proved himself to be as dexterous
as any bon rirant in the parish. But his
freak now drew to close ; poor piggy got
,as drunk as David's sow he caperel a.
bout, threw down the chairs. broke chr

full articles.headline: JANUARY 18, 1927
full articles.article:
by the very small compass Of perfectly gen
teel people like herself. Such an one with
a good subtantial fortune too, was to be
sourht.-Her stars favored her at last, how
ever. and she was married--marricd to a
Young gentlemen as accomplished as her.
self; one who had as many eulogies at his
finger ends, as buttons on his coat-an a.
b. and a profession; who drove tandem with
one hand; winged pigeon at every shot,
and drank nothing but Madeira.


1t was said the young gentleman and la
DIV were each little disappointed in the
matter of the others fortune, and that in
the outset there was tritlng jar onthe sub
ect Of finances, but Cornelia adhered to
her piano, and Bob to his rifle and Made
ria, and all went on quite musically again.
Neither OF them had ever suffered SO un-
manncrly thought, as that how to gct a
living when their cash was gone, enter their
head--but fortune in all these cases, has
plain matter of TACT way of dealing, with G.
ven the most gentccl people, and when they
spent their last dollar, just turns them out OF
house, as unceremoniously as it they were
no better than common folks.-She never
works n miracle to sustain those VINO new
er learned or had the disposition to work
anv thing themselves. And so it turned out
i'll this case.


While the piatlu IL tune in the par
4 lor, and every thing out OF tune IN the kitch-
en-; while the master drank MADEIRA above
stairs, and the servants were drunk with
corniuc below stairs, while in the midst oi
the best living and dreaming OF nothing out
pleasure and amusement, one OF bob's cred
4 itors raped his knuckles: the bailit1s are an
4 ill-bred set, they know just as much about


IL. ~ tI prt pf q { "a a
about a toilet, and therefore as might al
mos. have been expected, the carpets, the
plate, the sideboard, and even the very p!-
ano was levied on.


! Still SO far as physical ability was concern
cd it was not too late perhaps TO turn the
current Of affairs. There was a plain and
ready remedy for the disease, even in its
present state; an entire change OF living
and of habits; economy for Extravaganza
and industry for incidence. But hard it is
for these who have been thus educated to
/ change how often is the moral ability, the
! will wanting And here it proved to be the
case.


They struggled awhile to keep up appear
ance, and only sunk deeper in the end. len
wears after, thcy were almost forgotten. |
4 made many enquiries after them among the
villagers, and finally discovered that Robert
and his wife had separated; that he had eX-
changed his dog and gun for tar hat and
j blue Jacket, was wanderer on the sea; and
the elegant and accomplished Corntla, IN
stead of drumming piano, was gaming .
scanty subsistence At the spinning wheel
j So much for the story. Industry and vir'
tue are the best legacies parents can be-
queath to their offspring; the only sure de-
FENCES against misfortune. Let those who
are charged with the education Of children
beware. lest through an over anxiety tc


make them resncctable; to make them


proud, instead of cultivatng their genius,
! lead them to indoence. ! say beware

full articles.headline:
From lie Perry .3aecdotes.
IsIDEJ IrS
full articles.article:
Every one must recollect the traglcal sto-
ry of Young Elnmet tue Irish Patriot, It was
too touching to be soon forgotten During
the troubles in Ireland he was tried, con-
demncd, and executed on charge Of trea-
son. His fate made 4 deep impression on
public sympathy. He was 50 young; 50 N
selligent; 50 generous; SO bravc; so every
thing that we are apt to like in young man


His conduct under trial, too, was Lofty
and intrepid. The noiie indignation with
which he repealed the charge q treason a

full articles.headline:
.TYzE MONITOR.

TIE WAYS OF PROVIDENCE.
full articles.article:
The love of life is one of the most useful


and important priucinlcs of human nature;
and death, the necessary end OF all men, is
an event, mercifu!ly and in wisdom hid from
our eyes. Hoping that we may live till to-
morrow, we feel ourselves to day, to make
some provisions for it. Not knowing the
time of their death, men are engaged to.acts
as if they were immortal. And though no
wise man would "wish to live always" or
can deem it possible. yet the precise period
never comes, when we find ourselves SO en-
tirely unoccupied with temporal prospects
or pursuits, 30 totally mortified with the
world as to be disposed with cheerfulness to
leave it.-Hence the business OF the world
goes on, which would otherwise stand still;
and that God of whose years there can be
no end, is carving on designs of everlasting
moment. by frail and short lived instruments.
This man makes few feeble dying efforts,
and expires. Another comes after him,
takes UP the instrument which his fellow
had laid down, makes his stroke or TWO,
and exprca likewise; and yet by means OF
efforts so weak, so interrupted, and sell de-
stroyng, the purposes OF Heaven proceed,
the building Of God rises, every loss is IN
stantly repaired, every defect supplied, nc
chasn, in the chain of Providence is permit
ted to take place. Hence men are disnihed
with the title of fellow workers OF God, and
the perishing attempts OF Pcri'hng crea-
lures, are employed i'll maturing the plans ol
infinite wisdom, and arc honored by the &C
ceptance and appropriation OF linn whe
"worketh all things after the counsel OF his
own wilt" What a motive to diligence,
cxertion and perseverance


1t is said that we may safely leave rcli-
eion to itself; and that the work OF God, II
really his work, will be able to stand OF itself
and can require no human aid 1t would be
sufficient answer to this sophism, that II
would be conclusive against all efforts OF all
sects for the religious instruction and I'M
provcment of the human race, and would
reduce us all, as respects religion to crea-
lures of necessity, for why should there DC
any preacher to teach, if it is to be commu-
| nicated without teaching? But this is not


the principal either of reason or religion
| The manifest reason is, that God always


works by secondary causes, and requires the
best exercise of our rational powers; and oul
means of all kinds, both to receive religious
| instruction for ourselves, and 10 convey 1t &c


others; and that in proportion as NATIONS Of
| individuals possess these means, they are
answerablc to him for the due and right use
of them. There are therefore two main
reasons for religious instruction, the first oul
duty to ourselves, inasmuch as God requires
this duty of us an act of service and homage


to Him, and without any reference 70 tle


certainty of success, and secondly as duty


to our neighhors. We are bound to maks


the attempt however unpromisng as an ac
| of service, and of obedience to God, and we
are bound TO persevere in it, because the


slightest success is a good communicated tt


our neighbor, and reward insured to our


selves infinitely above all the possible cos'


of mere money and personal pains.

full articles.headline:
PD-Hz-Ers2sYa >

FAITHLESS NELLY GRAY.
full articles.article:
we extract the following pathetic balla
rom the last number of the London Literar
Gazette received at this Office. 1t is take
rom an amusing work lately published
fordon. under the title of Ithims and odd
.es in prose and verse, by Thomas Hood.


" Y. Statesman.
Ben Battle was soldier bold,
And used to wars alarms,
But cannon ball took off his legs,
So lie laid down his arms!
Now as thev bore him off the field,
Said he, s'let others shoot,
For here leave my second leg,
And the sForty.second Foot
The army.snrgeons made him limbsi
Said he, they're only pegs;
But there's as wooden members quite
As represent my lcgs!'
Now Ben he loved pretty maid,
Her name was Nelly Gray;
So he went to pay her his dcvours,
Wien he dcvour'd his pay!
But when he calld on Nelly Gray,
She made him quite a scott;
And when she saw his wooden legs,
Began to take them off!
% Nelly Gray! o Nelly Gray!
Is this your love SO warm
The love that loves scarlet coat,
Should be more uniform!
Said she, q loy'l soldier once,
For he was blthe and brayei
But will never have a man


With both legs in the grave!
Before you had those timber toes,
Your love did allow;
But then, you know, you stand upon
Another footing now!'
20 Nelly Gray! Nelly Gray!
For all your jeering speeches,
At duty's call left my lcgs


In Badajos' breachesh
why them said she, you've lost the feet
Oflegs in wars alarms;
And now you cannot wearyour shoes
Upon your feats of alins!'
false and tickle Nelly Gray


know why you refuse;
Tho I've no feet, some other man
lsstandng in my shoes!
wish ne.er had seen your facei
But now long farewell!
For ysu will be my death-alas


You will not be my NeH"
Now when he went from Nelly Gray.


His heart so heavy got,
And life was such burden grown


1t made him take knot!
So round his melancholy neck


rope he did entwine,
And, for the second time in life,


Enlisted in the Line!
One end he tied around beam,


And then remov'd his pegs
And, as his legs We're Off, Of course,


lie soon was off his legs!
And ,tere he hung till he was dead
As any nail in town;
For no distress had cut him up,


II could not cut him down.
dozen men sat on his corpse,


10 lind out why he died;
And they buried Ben in four crossroads,


With stake in his inside!

gainst his country; the eloquent yindication
of his name; and his pathetic appeal to pos
terity in the hopeless hour Of contemplation;
all these entered deeply into every generous
bosom, and even his opponents lamented the
stern policy that dictated his execution.


But there was one heart whose anguish it
would be impossible to describe. In haPpi-
er days and fairer fortunes he had won the
affections OF beautiful and interesting girl,
the daughter of the late celebrated Irish
barrister. She loved him with the disiuter-
ested fervor of a woman's first and early
love. When every worldly maxim arrayed
itself against him, when blasted in fortune.
and disgrace and danger darkened around
his name, she loved him the more ardently
for his sufferings. Since his fate could a.
waken sympathy even of his foes, what must
have been the agony of her, whose soul was
occupied by his image? Let those tell who
have had the portals of the tomb suddenly
closed between them and the being they
most loved ON earth; who have sat at its
threshold, as one shut out in cold and lcne-
ly world, whence all that was lovely and low
ing had departed.


To render her widowed situation more
desolate, she had incurred her fathers dis
pleasure by her unfortunate attachment,
and was an exile from the paternal roof
But could the sympathy and kind offices OF
friends have reached spirit so shocked and
driven in by horror, she would have expert
enced no want of consolation, for the Irish
are people of quick and generous sensibili-
ties. The most delicate and cherishing at
tentions were paid her by families of wealth
| and distinction.--She was led into society,
and they tried all kinds of occupation and
amusement, to dissipate her grief, wean her
from the tragical story of her love, but all
was in vain! There are some strokes of ca
lamity that scathe and scorch the soul--that
penetrate to the vital seat of happiness, and
blast it, never again to put forth bud or blos-
som. She never objected to frequent the
haunts OF otpleasure; but she was as much a.
lone there as in the depths Of Solitude. She
| carried with her an inward woe, that mock
ed all the Establishments of friendship, and
"heeded not the song of the charmer; charm
lie ever so wisely"


The person, says the eloquent author Of
the Sketch Book, who told me her storys
had seen her at masquerade. After STROLL
ing through the splendid rooms and giddy
crowd, with an air of utter abstraction, she
sat herself down on the steps of an orchestra,
and looking about for some time with va
cant air, that showed her insensbility tsthe
garlsh scene, she began with the capricious-
ness of heart, to warble a little plaintive air.
She had an exquisite voice; but on this occa-
sion was so simple, so touching, it breathed
forth such soul of wretchedness that sh~
drew crowd, mute and silent are..iio her.
and melted every one into tears.
The story of one SO true and tender, could
not but excite great interest in a country re-
markable for enthusiasm. 1t completely
won the heart OF a brave officer, who paid
his addresses to her, and thought that one SO
! t,u,a to tbaf RI ..J J,,.
tomato to the living. She declined his atten-
tions, tor her thoughts were rrevocably en-
crossed by the memory of her former lover.
He solicited not her tenderness, but her es-
TEEN. lie was assisted by her conviction Of
his worth, and her sense OF her own destitute
and dependant situation, for she was exist
ing on the kindness of friends In word
he at length succeeded in gaining her hand,
/ though with a solemn assurance that her
heart was unalterably anothcr's.


| He took her with him to Sicily, heping
that change of scene might wear out the
remembrance of early woes. She was an
amiable and exemplary wife, and made an
effort to be happy one; but nothing could
cure the silent melancholy that had entered
into her very soul. She wasted away in q
slow but hopeless decline, and at last sunk
into the grave, the victim of a broken heart.
~ "Ho va t'io tooJ, tuae AFAOOiC SoNlPOaS
ed the following lines:


She is fur from the land where her young hero


sleeps,


| And lovers around her are signing;


But codly she turns from their gaze and weeps.


For her heart in his grave is lying


She sings the wild song of her dear native plains,
! Every note which he lov'd awaking;


All! little they think, who delight in her strains,
I How the heart Of the minstrel is breaking!


lie had lived for his love-for his country he


died,


They were all that to life had entwn'd him,


Nor soon shall the tears Of his country DC dried.


Nor long will his love stay behind ln''


OH make her grave whore the s,nbeams rest,


When they promise glorious mor"ow;
They'll slime Ger her sleep, like smile from the
1 west,


From her own loy'd Island of sorrow!
A PROFLIGATE PIG.


~. ,rnaeI.v a Dersou living in Maidstone

who we shall introdue to our readers under
the name of Jonah Coffin. Poising his har-
poon, he firmly awaited the orders of his su-
perior, then seated on the boats stern. Be-
fore him, forcing itself furiously onward,
was huge andupcouth mass, alternately e.
mittng from its glossy protuberances, the
sparkling effulgcnce of a meridian sun, or
partially descending below the temporary
surge, forming little vortices to its wake,
and putting from its nostris the encroaching
brine. Long and patiently did the oarsmen
tug at their stations-"pull away" said the
officer encouragingly, while he drew towards
him the handle ef his steering oar. The We
nv eye of the monster was now in sight
'snow dart" exclaimed the mate; and Jo-
nah, with the effort OF Polyphemus, drove
the weapon. fast into the body of his gigantic
antagonist


It. was an awful moment; and the adven-
turous fishers had made every customary
preparation for its reception. But the OBJ


cct Of their toll. instead of dropping instan-
taneously into the depths beneath, thence a.
gain to emerge, after some moments, tor the
sake ofbrcath--or instead of starting Oft hor-
izontally, as is frequently the case, with the
velocity of lightning, dragging his presump-
tuous pursuers through the disparting wave,
which throws swiftly upon either side OF
their frail pinnance a transparent sheet of
spray, surmounted by gorgeous ranbows-
rolled backward, and with preternatural
frenzy made for the boat-his enormous
laws distcndcd to their utmost limits; and
lis tremendous tail now curvingi upwards,
and vibrating like a light house in an earth
quake, and anon falling with horrid flap up
on the level bosom of the sounding deep
The astonshca sailors we're about to rush
overheard, when, with convulsive sound,
1t was the leap of a mountan--the lace
rated monster sprang entirely over the boat,
his unearthly dimensions striking principal
ly upon the opposite side, and partly upon
the fragile bark itself, spiling its contents
and grinding its frame to splinters.


The men were all good swimmers, and,
save one, betook themselves, without farther
calculation, and with exemplary preciptan-
cy, to the profitable exercise Of their arms
and legs-whereby they soon reached the
boats Of their comrades, and were out of
danger. Not SO with poor Ionah.--In the
tumult of the moment, he had become en-
tangled in the tortuous coil attached to the
harpoon. Not AN instant had been allowed
lin, wherein he might haye seized the
Ratchet, or unsheathed his jacknife, and
freed himself from SO ungracous predica-
meut. He felt himself drawn, by an ire
sstible power, down, down, amidst intermi-
nable cavcrns, and bottomless profundties.
| What greatly surprised him, was his ability
still to breathe and to see. Passing, with
the rapitlity Of thought, along immeasurable
distances, he had opportunities to scan but
few Of the wonders of those vast quits,
| Here lay an extensive forest Of coral, inhab-
! tied BY shapes abe--there moved
an immense mass of gelatnous matter, en-
compasscd by myriads of submarine prodi-
| gies, to piscivorous man hitherto unknown.
| The a-devil, with his emerald horns; the
tartarean crab, with a million claws, each a
furlong in length; the ponderous symmesian
oyster, whose shells open wide enough to
admit a seventy-fOur; the thousand eyed
dragon, whose head, studded with a thou
sand gems, and whose eyes, set in countless
diamonds, may be seen at the depth of five
hundred fathoms; sta-gorgons, hydras, grif-


fins, phnnixes, and all manner Of beau
tiful reptiles, were quietly feeding, or frolc-
ing without any noise, in those unsearchable
regions.


| And here, some philosophers may be dis
posed to obtrude doubt, touching honest
I Jonah's capacity of vision and of respiration
the whilc.-Rut let it be inquired, whether
/ Il


with such outrageous celebrity, may not have
left behind sort of vacuity, aflording me-


dunn wherein the little animal in his rear
might exercise those faculties? And, re-


garding the accelerated progress of this


monster it may be aptly accounted for on
purely philosophical principles: every body


knows how fast dog will run with kettle
|
I But to our tale--iet us hasten to the ca


tastrophe. After being carried to such


lengths, and in such manner, our almost


exhausted hero, found himself on the ascent.


His wild and turbulent conductor was again


mounting to the upper world. Embracing a


moment of respite, while the whale was 10


the act of turning upon his side, he sought


his knife--but III yain--2 new motion dis


turbed him---he was waved to and fro with


an impetuous gularity--his lungs labour-


ed, and his sight grew indistinct--his breatl,


went, and came, and went, to return not


without inhaling also draught Of the saline


fluid. Alas thought he, am drowned =


Foggy images fioated on his brain, and grad


ually faded into otluscatioa. He awoke up


on the quarter deck of his own snip, under


the oepration OF stimula,i,e cordials and


warm towels; having been cast upon the


surface during the whales DIVING struggle


and picked up near the place Of his descent
